com.complexible.stardog.plan.filter.functions

Interface Function

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractFunction

    public interface Function

    Interface for a Function which computes a Value given some number of input values.

    This is the extension point for 17.6 (Extensible Value Testing) of the SPARQL spec.

    For implementations of Function to be visible to the query parser and engine, they must be registered via the JDK ServiceLoader. Create a file called com.complexible.stardog.plan.filter.functions.Function in the META-INF/services directory. The contents of this file should be all of the *fully-qualified* class names for the custom Functions. Then if a jar containing the META-INF/services directory and the implementations for the Functions is included on the classpath, Stardog will pick up the implementations on startup.

    Since:
    0.1
    Version:
    2.1
    Author:
    Michael Grove
    See Also:
    FunctionRegistry, Extension Functions

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        String getName()
        Return the string that uniquely identifies this Function, which should be a fully qualified URI. This URI is what is used to reference this Function in a SPARQL query.
        Returns:
        the URI

      • getNames

        List<String> getNames()
        Return all the strings that uniquely identifies this Function. A function may have different names in different namespaces.
        Returns:
        all aliases of this Function
        See Also:
        getName()

      • evaluate

        org.openrdf.model.Value evaluate(org.openrdf.model.Value... theArgs)
                                 throws FunctionEvaluationException
        Evaluate this function. The provided arguments, if any, are the current bindings for the input values. To use the example from the SPARQL spec, if the Function is used in a query aGeo:distance(?axLoc, ?ayLoc, ?bxLoc, ?byLoc) , its signature is as follows: 
         {code
      xsd:double   aGeo:distance (numeric x1, numeric y1, numeric x2, numeric y2)
 }
        When evaluate is called, it will be provided four values, which are the current values for the parameters, x1, y1, x2, and y2.
        Parameters:
        theArgs - the arguments to the function
        Returns:
        the result of the function execution
        Throws:
        FunctionEvaluationException - if there is an error while evaluating the function

      • initialize

        @Beta
Function initialize()
        Initialize this function. In the case of a pure function, this is a no-op and simply returns the same object (ie this == this.initialize()). However, in some cases, a function needs to keep some global state during query execution for it to work correctly. initialize should prepare the function for execution by either clearing or otherwise preparing it's state for (re)execution, or creating a new function suitable for use in the subsequent execution.
        Returns:
        an initialized version of this function, potentially a *new* instance of the function.

      • getArity

        Range<Integer> getArity()
        Return the number of arguments the function accepts. A range is used to indicate the minimum and/or maximum number of arguments; in some cases the number of arguments a function takes is variable.
        Returns:
        the function arity
